ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Research, and how to give a symposium talk
I learned a lot about my own topic as well as how to conduct basic scientific (secondary) research. In particular, I learned how to sift through basic academic papers and grasp meaning / approach.

I think the ability to take a particular biological issue or heavily discussed topic, and not only research this topic but craft a narrative around what's going on and even put forth your own argument.
I learned a lot more about science in general than I did in high school.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very accessible science credit for non-science majors.

The course is a little strange. It's more of a directed reading class than anything else, but it's unclear whether the paper is supposed to be an argument or a survey of current literature, and though in both cases I learn a lot, its difficult to tell. I didn't think the weekly updates on our project were effective, though I admit I can't think of what else I would suggest. I actually think that allocating half the class to updates, and half the class to a preassigned topic would be very helpful -- kind of like the Snow reading we did in the first week.

I liked how we are able to learn in-depth about a subject of our choice, through research with the great guidance of Professor Summers. The course also allow you to learn quite a bit about other biological hot topics through other students's research papers and updates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely take this course if you need a science credit (if you can get in). It is an easy course and if you choose an interesting topic, you will be engaged all semester.

This class is just a directed reading class oriented around a final paper. No work at all in the class but you won't learn all that much either. Take if you're just trying to get through the science credit or if you have a topic you really want to engage with deeply with the whole semester.
yes! It was very fun but also informative!
